text: In reading over the assignment, I do see that it is confusing/wrong. In part (3) I used _m_ where I meant to use _n_ in both places. The other source of possible confusion is that you might think that (lambda) function _f_ has to be the sort method itself. Not at all. You need to write a lambda which takes an _Integer_ (_T_) and sorts that number of elements from a (static) array. After all, you don't want to be instantiating and populating the array for every repetition. I'm sorry I didn't make that clearer.
I have extended the deadline for assignment 3 until Thursday at 3pm and I have updated the description on Blackboard.

<!channel> On further reflection, I am going to add some additional code for assignment 3 so that you will have less to do. Please hold off working on it for now. I expect to extend the deadline again.
I have added the extra code to the repository. Please do a pull. There are five files that have changed, of which four are relevant to this assignment.
If you already did a pull in the last 20 minutes, please do another one.
I have done more refactoring (of the entire repository). I suggest doing another pull now.

If you are using an IDE like IntelliJ/IDEA you can always look for TODOs my opening up the tool window for TODO (#6). TODO is a mainstay of software engineering and not just something we use in these assignments.
hi, prof, we don't necessarily have use Benchmark.java from the github COMPLETELY, right? As long as we can meet the assignment requirement.
Yes, thatâ€™s correct, but I strongly recommend you to use the Benchmark class. You just have to implement the TODOs then.
